habitat_description:
The range of this species extends from coastal California areas in the vicinity of Salinas, Monterey County, south to areas nearby El Rosario in northern Baja California. Isolated populations are found further south to the La Presa region of southern Baja California (Grismer 2002; Jennings and Hayes 1994; McGuire and Grismer 1993; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

This highly aquatic snake is associated with creeks and medium sized rivers, but also inhabits a series of riparian environments. This species is known to burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter. Populations occur nearby permanent fresh water, along streams with rocky beds often associated with willows. Its habitat also includes mountain slopes and desert oases (Grismer 2002; Jennings and Hayes 1994; Rossman et al. 1996; Stebbins 2003).

SW-Primarily associated with riparian vegetation (i.e. willows), uses leaf litter, fallen logs, and soft soils as cover.
